protocol_name: Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
protocol_name_html: Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
description:
This is a modified version of the DNA extraction methods published in:
Rowan, R., & Powers, D.A. (1991) Molecular genetic identification of symbiotic dinoflagellates (zooxanthellae). Marine Ecology Progress Series, 71(1), 65–73.
Baker, A.C., Rowan, R., & Knowlton, N. (1997) Symbiosis ecology of two Caribbean acroporid corals. Proceedings of the 8th International Coral Reef Symposium, Panama 2: 1295-1300

This protocol is used to extract and purify genomic DNA from coral samples (tissue and skeleton) that is suitable for PCR, qPCR, sequencing, and other downstream applications. DNA is recovered from the coral host, Symbiodinium, and other members of the holobiont.
manuscript_citation: Putnam HM, Davidson JM, Gates RD, Ocean acidification influences host methylation and phenotypic plasticity in environmentally susceptible corals. Evolutionary Applications 9(9). doi: 10.1111/eva.12408

components.data:
Acquire sample material.
Small amounts of coral tissue, with or without skeleton, may be obtained by clipping off branch tips, scraping with a razor blade, etc.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
source_data.protocol_name: Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
source_data.protocol_name_html: Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
source_data.annotation: Greater success in downstream PCR amplification is generally achieved when the amount of starting material is small. Tissue scrapings or biopsies are ideal for the in situ digests described here using SDS and Proteinase K. Larger core samples or colony fragments are not recommended - in this case blast the tissue off the skeleton first using an airbrush or Water Pik and then centrifuge the blastate and lyse cells in 1% SDS and digest with Proteinase K.
source_data.thread_text: Greater success in downstream PCR amplification is generally achieved when the amount of starting material is small. Tissue scrapings or biopsies are ideal for the in situ digests described here using SDS and Proteinase K. Larger core samples or colony fragments are not recommended - in this case blast the tissue off the skeleton first using an airbrush or Water Pik and then centrifuge the blastate and lyse cells in 1% SDS and digest with Proteinase K.
source_data.body: Greater success in downstream PCR amplification is generally achieved when the amount of starting material is small. Tissue scrapings or biopsies are ideal for the in situ digests described here using SDS and Proteinase K. Larger core samples or colony fragments are not recommended - in this case blast the tissue off the skeleton first using an airbrush or Water Pik and then centrifuge the blastate and lyse cells in 1% SDS and digest with Proteinase K.

components.data: Add sample to 500 µL 1% SDS in DNAB in a microcentrifuge tube. Be sure that sample is fully immersed in the buffer. Incubate sample for 60-90 minutes at 65°C. Sample is now stabilized for storage at room temperature, and can be treated as an "archive" for future use. These archives can be used for multiple attempts at DNA extraction.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add sample to 500 µL 1% SDS in DNAB in a microcentrifuge tube. Be sure that sample is fully immersed in the buffer. Incubate sample for 60-90 minutes at 65°C. Sample is now stabilized for storage at room temperature, and can be treated as an "archive" for future use. These archives can be used for multiple attempts at DNA extraction.

components.data: SDS Incubation
components.name: Section

source_data.description:
This buffer is used to stabilize samples for archiving and subsequentgenomic DNA extraction. 

SDS is dissolved to a concentration of 1% (w/v) in DNAB (DNA buffer: 0.4 M NaCl + 0.05 M EDTA in MilliQ water). The buffer may need to be warmed for SDS to completely dissolve. Tissue samples are added to small aliquots of 1% SDS in DNAB and heated to 65°C for 60-90 minutes. They are then stable at room temperature and ready for extraction of genomic DNA.
source_data.manuscript_citation: Putnam HM, Davidson JM, Gates RD, Ocean acidification influences host methylation and phenotypic plasticity in environmentally susceptible corals. Evolutionary Applications 9(9). doi: 10.1111/eva.12408
source_data.guidelines: SDS is dissolved to a concentration of 1% (w/v) in DNAB (DNA buffer: 0.4 M NaCl + 0.05 M EDTA in MilliQ water). The buffer may need to be warmed for SDS to completely dissolve. Tissue samples are added to small aliquots of 1% SDS in DNAB and heated to 65°C for 60-90 minutes. They are then stablle at room temperature and ready for extraction of genomic DNA.

source_data.description: Prepare stock solution of 0.5 M EDTA in MilliQ water

components.data: Mix 50 mL 4 M NaCl and 50 mL 0.5 M EDTA
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Mix 50 mL 4 M NaCl and 50 mL 0.5 M EDTA

components.data: Make up to a final volume of 500 mL with MilliQ water
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make up to a final volume of 500 mL with MilliQ water

components.data:
Dissolve SDS in DNA Buffer to a final concentration of 1% (w/v).
e.g., 5 g SDS in 500 mL of DNA Buffer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Dissolve SDS in DNA Buffer to a final concentration of 1% (w/v).
e.g., 5 g SDS in 500 mL of DNA Buffer.

components.data: Add 25 µL Proteinase K (10 mg/mL) to sample archive and vortex well. Incubate overnight at 37°C, for 6-7 hours at 45°C, or for 2-3 hours at 55°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 25 µL Proteinase K (10 mg/mL) to sample archive and vortex well. Incubate overnight at 37°C, for 6-7 hours at 45°C, or for 2-3 hours at 55°C.

components.data: Proteinase K digest
components.name: Section

components.data: Prepare a new set of 1.5 mL tubes for the samples you intend to process, and add 100 µL of each sample archive (in 1% SDS in DNAB) to the new set of tubes. Return the remainder of the sample archive to storage.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare a new set of 1.5 mL tubes for the samples you intend to process, and add 100 µL of each sample archive (in 1% SDS in DNAB) to the new set of tubes. Return the remainder of the sample archive to storage.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
source_data.protocol_name: Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
source_data.protocol_name_html: Bulk gDNA extraction from coral samples
source_data.annotation: DNA can be extracted from any quantity of sample archive. The protocol given here is written for extractions of 100 µL of the sample archive, but volumes can be proportionally adjusted up to the second ethanol precipitation if desired (e.g., to increase absolute DNA yields).
source_data.thread_text: DNA can be extracted from any quantity of sample archive. The protocol given here is written for extractions of 100 µL of the sample archive, but volumes can be proportionally adjusted up to the second ethanol precipitation if desired (e.g., to increase absolute DNA yields).
source_data.body: DNA can be extracted from any quantity of sample archive. The protocol given here is written for extractions of 100 µL of the sample archive, but volumes can be proportionally adjusted up to the second ethanol precipitation if desired (e.g., to increase absolute DNA yields).

components.data: Defrost CTAB mix (stored at -20°C) and add twice volume (200 µL) to each sample. Vortex and incubate at 65°C for 30-60 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Defrost CTAB mix (stored at -20°C) and add twice volume (200 µL) to each sample. Vortex and incubate at 65°C for 30-60 minutes.

components.data: Organic extraction
components.name: Section

source_data.description:
This solution is used in the coral genomic DNA extraction protocol.

The following recipe is for 50 mL of CTAB mix. Store at -20°C.
source_data.manuscript_citation: Putnam HM, Davidson JM, Gates RD, Ocean acidification influences host methylation and phenotypic plasticity in environmentally susceptible corals. Evolutionary Applications 9(9). doi: 10.1111/eva.12408

components.data: Dissolve 0.75 g CTAB in ~ 20 mL MilliQ water
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dissolve 0.75 g CTAB in ~ 20 mL MilliQ water

components.data: Add 12.5 mL of 4 M NaCl
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 12.5 mL of 4 M NaCl

components.data: Add 75 µL of E. coli tRNA at 20 mg/mL
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 75 µL of E. coli tRNA at 20 mg/mL

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of CTAB mix
source_data.annotation: E. coli tRNA is used as a carrier nucleic acid to boost total nucleic acid concentrations and increase the extraction yield
source_data.thread_text: E. coli tRNA is used as a carrier nucleic acid to boost total nucleic acid concentrations and increase the extraction yield
source_data.body: E. coli tRNA is used as a carrier nucleic acid to boost total nucleic acid concentrations and increase the extraction yield

components.data: Make up to a final volume of 50 mL with MilliQ water
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make up to a final volume of 50 mL with MilliQ water

components.data: Allow samples to cool. In fume hood, add equal volume (300 µL) of chloroform. Be sure to ‘charge’ (i.e., fill and empty pipette tip with chloroform 2 to 3 times) the pipette tip before first use, or your tip will leak chloroform. Vortex sample and invert several times, but be careful that caps are tight – leaking chloroform will erase your sample labels! Put in rack on rotating platform for 2-3 hours.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow samples to cool. In fume hood, add equal volume (300 µL) of chloroform. Be sure to ‘charge’ (i.e., fill and empty pipette tip with chloroform 2 to 3 times) the pipette tip before first use, or your tip will leak chloroform. Vortex sample and invert several times, but be careful that caps are tight – leaking chloroform will erase your sample labels! Put in rack on rotating platform for 2-3 hours.

source_data.annotation: This timer is incorrect. Protocol says 2-3 hrs not 5 mins.
source_data.thread_text: This timer is incorrect. Protocol says 2-3 hrs not 5 mins.
source_data.body: This timer is incorrect. Protocol says 2-3 hrs not 5 mins.

components.data: Centrifuge at 10,000g (RCF) for 10 minutes. Align tubes in centrifuge so that hinges are on the outside. While spinning, prepare a new set of labeled 1.5 mL tubes. Remove samples from centrifuge and very carefully pipette off top ~250 µL into new tube. Dispose the rest of the contents into appropriate waste container.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Centrifuge at 10,000g (RCF) for 10 minutes. Align tubes in centrifuge so that hinges are on the outside. While spinning, prepare a new set of labeled 1.5 mL tubes. Remove samples from centrifuge and very carefully pipette off top ~250 µL into new tube. Dispose the rest of the contents into appropriate waste container.

components.data: First ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

components.data: Add twice volume (500 µL) of 100% (200-proof) ethanol (EtOH). Ensure caps are shut tightly and invert samples in their rack several times, together with a few brief shakes to make sure samples are well mixed.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add twice volume (500 µL) of 100% (200-proof) ethanol (EtOH). Ensure caps are shut tightly and invert samples in their rack several times, together with a few brief shakes to make sure samples are well mixed.

components.data: First ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

components.data: Put samples in freezer for at least 2 hours to promote DNA precipitation. If the EtOH is pre-chilled, you can leave it in the -20°C freezer for only a 1/2 hour.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Put samples in freezer for at least 2 hours to promote DNA precipitation. If the EtOH is pre-chilled, you can leave it in the -20°C freezer for only a 1/2 hour.

components.data: First ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

source_data.annotation: Potential stopping point. Keep samples in freezer to allow DNA to precipitate.
source_data.thread_text: Potential stopping point. Keep samples in freezer to allow DNA to precipitate.
source_data.body: Potential stopping point. Keep samples in freezer to allow DNA to precipitate.

components.data: Put samples in centrifuge (ensuring that the hinges of the tubes are on the outside) and spin for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Put samples in centrifuge (ensuring that the hinges of the tubes are on the outside) and spin for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF).

components.data: Second ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

components.data: Remove samples from centrifuge and carefully decant off ethanol from all the tubes into a waste container. The DNA pellet should remain stuck to the inside of the tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove samples from centrifuge and carefully decant off ethanol from all the tubes into a waste container. The DNA pellet should remain stuck to the inside of the tube.

components.data: Second ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

components.data: Put tubes, with their caps open, in the Vacufuge/Speedvac. Be careful when putting the tubes in and don’t touch the inside of the caps. Speedvac at 45°C for 30-60 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Put tubes, with their caps open, in the Vacufuge/Speedvac. Be careful when putting the tubes in and don’t touch the inside of the caps. Speedvac at 45°C for 30-60 minutes.

components.data: Second ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

components.data: Remove samples from vacufuge and add 100 µL of 0.3 M NaOAc (do not use the stock 3 M solution!). Vortex sample well to dissolve pellet. When the pellet is dissolved the sample will appear “syrupy” and will not bounce around as droplets inside the tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove samples from vacufuge and add 100 µL of 0.3 M NaOAc (do not use the stock 3 M solution!). Vortex sample well to dissolve pellet. When the pellet is dissolved the sample will appear “syrupy” and will not bounce around as droplets inside the tube.

components.data: Second ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

source_data.description: Sodium acetate solution is used in DNA extraction. This recipe makes 50 mL of a 3 M stock solution at ph 5.2  -- dilute tenfold in water to a working concentration of 0.3 M for use in the DNA extraction protocol.
source_data.manuscript_citation: Putnam HM, Davidson JM, Gates RD, Ocean acidification influences host methylation and phenotypic plasticity in environmentally susceptible corals. Evolutionary Applications 9(9). doi: 10.1111/eva.12408

components.data: Dissolve 12.3 g of Sodium acetate (anhydrous) in ~ 40 mL MilliQ water.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dissolve 12.3 g of Sodium acetate (anhydrous) in ~ 40 mL MilliQ water.

components.data: Adjust pH to 5.2 with glacial acetic acid
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Adjust pH to 5.2 with glacial acetic acid

components.data: Make up to 50 mL with MilliQ water
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make up to 50 mL with MilliQ water

components.data: Dilute an aliquot of the 3 M stock solution to 0.3 M for use in the DNA extraction protocol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Dilute an aliquot of the 3 M stock solution to 0.3 M for use in the DNA extraction protocol.

components.data: Once the pellet is dissolved, add 200uL of 100% Ethanol, vortex and invert several times and put in freezer for at least 2hrs.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once the pellet is dissolved, add 200uL of 100% Ethanol, vortex and invert several times and put in freezer for at least 2hrs.

components.data: Second ethanol precipitation
components.name: Section

source_data.annotation: Potential stopping point. Keep sample in freezer to allow DNA to precipitate
source_data.thread_text: Potential stopping point. Keep sample in freezer to allow DNA to precipitate
source_data.body: Potential stopping point. Keep sample in freezer to allow DNA to precipitate

components.data: Remove samples from freezer, and centrifuge for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF). Decant supernatant into appropriate waste container.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove samples from freezer, and centrifuge for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF). Decant supernatant into appropriate waste container.

components.data: Ethanol wash
components.name: Section

components.data: Add 100 µL of 70% Ethanol, and vortex thoroughly (this is the “Ethanol Wash” step). Centrifuge for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF), and again decant supernatant into appropriate waste container.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 100 µL of 70% Ethanol, and vortex thoroughly (this is the “Ethanol Wash” step). Centrifuge for 10 minutes at 10,000g (RCF), and again decant supernatant into appropriate waste container.

components.data: Ethanol wash
components.name: Section

source_data.description: Mix 7 parts of 100% Ethanol (200-proof) and 3 parts MilliQ water.
source_data.manuscript_citation: Putnam HM, Davidson JM, Gates RD, Ocean acidification influences host methylation and phenotypic plasticity in environmentally susceptible corals. Evolutionary Applications 9(9). doi: 10.1111/eva.12408

components.data: Put samples in Vacufuge with the caps open, and speedvac at 45°C for 30-60 minutes to thoroughly dry the pellet.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Put samples in Vacufuge with the caps open, and speedvac at 45°C for 30-60 minutes to thoroughly dry the pellet.

components.data: Ethanol wash
components.name: Section

components.data: Take samples out of centrifuge and add 50-100 µL TE buffer. Vortex briefly to mix and store at -20°C in freezer. Sample is now ready for PCR. Store DNA samples at -20°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Take samples out of centrifuge and add 50-100 µL TE buffer. Vortex briefly to mix and store at -20°C in freezer. Sample is now ready for PCR. Store DNA samples at -20°C.

components.data: Resuspension of purified DNA
components.name: Section

source_data.description: This TE buffer contains 10 mM Tris and 0.1 mM EDTA for storage of nucleic acids. Concentration of EDTA is lower than other formulations of TE buffer so that EDTA will not inhibit Taq Polymerase in downstream PCR reactions.
source_data.manuscript_citation: Putnam HM, Davidson JM, Gates RD, Ocean acidification influences host methylation and phenotypic plasticity in environmentally susceptible corals. Evolutionary Applications 9(9). doi: 10.1111/eva.12408
